bibl.title: Letter from William C. Rucker to [Hugh S. Cumming], March 5, 1923

div1.p: Rucker reports on possible cases of yellow fever in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

div1.head: Letter from William C. Rucker to [Hugh S. Cumming], March 5, 1923
div1.opener:
Copy.
Office of
Medical Officer in Charge.
Treasury Department,
United States
Public Health Service.
Balboa Heights, Canal Zone,
March 5, 1923.
Surgeon General,
United States Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
The reported occurrence of seven cases of ictero hemorrhagic fever,
with four deaths, in the city of Guayaquil, Ecuador, raised the ques-
tion in this office as to whether or not there might be a recurrence
of yellow fever in that port. In this connection, copies of cable-
grams are quoted below, which are self-explanatory.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, (Signed) W. C. Rucker.
W. C. RUCKER
Surgeon, U. S. P. H. S.
Chief Quarantine Officer, The Panama Canal. --------------------------------------------------------------------------
Cable from Chief Health Officer, The Panama Canal, Fev. 26, 1923.
“Dr. Wensceslao Pareja, Guayaquil, Ecuador:
Seven cases ictero-hemorrhagic fever with four deaths reported in
Guayaquil. Please cable accurate diagnosis these cases and statement
whether or not yellow fever and if disease spreading.”
----------------
Cable reply from Dr. Pareja; dated Feb. 28, 1923.
“Col. Fisher, Chief Health Officer, Balboa:
During year 1922 only one proven case ictero hemorrhagic fever coming
from the field. Six merely suspected cases not proved, but none suspected
as yellow fever recently numerous foreigners have immigrated several bat-
tallions of troops from the highlands no suspect cases stegomyia absolutely
inoffensive I guarantee Guayaquil to be immune any case would be immedia-
tely communicated without reserve.”
